newsitem.title: EGYPT: Egyptian state to sell 25 pct of export bank.
newsitem.headline: Egyptian state to sell 25 pct of export bank.

text.p: The Egyptian state will sell 25 percent of state-dominated Export Development Bank of Egypt through a public share offering by November 1, state television said on Wednesday.
It will also raise the bank's paid-in capital to 250 million pounds ($73 million) from 69 million and its authorised capital to 500 million from 100 million, it said.
It quoted Information Minister and government spokesman Safwat el-Sharif, speaking after the weekly cabinet meeting.
The television did not say which of the two operations would come first or how exactly they were related.
Of all the Egyptian banks undergoing partial privatisation, the export bank is the one closest to the state.
State-owned financial institutions own about 98 percent of the bank and the 690,000 shares rarely trade on the stock exchange. They were last quoted at 100 pounds in October 1995.
In calendar 1995 the bank made a net after-tax profit of 36.052 million pounds, against 31.097 million the previous year. It paid out a dividend of 25 pounds.
Egyptian officials repeatedly say they will not privatise the four big public-sector retail banks.
